div.p: The ∆t super-script illustrates that this quantity depends on the computational time interval, though we will omit this superscript for notational simplicity. The specification of a basic model within this framework thus requires specifying how the quantities {τ c n } and {Q c n ,c m } depend on factors of interest. We describe a few such specific models in the subsequent sections.

div.head: Similarity-based Attention
div.p: Here we illustrate how attention effects can be encoded in the deliberation time component of the model ({τ c n }) and how this factor alone can account for classic context effects in multi-alternative, multi-attribute choice. Following Tversky and Simonson (1993) and many other models of context effects (Noguchi & Stewart, 2018;Trueblood et al., 2014;Wollschläger & Diederich, 2012), we consider a pairwise model where the referent to which an alternative is compared is another alternative in the choice set. A comparison then is determined by the two alternatives (i, j) being compared along with the attribute (a) that is being attended to:
. For further simplicity and to illustrate the effect of this model factor on its own, we will assume that all possible comparisons are equally likely so that Q c n ,c m is the same for all n ̸ = m.
We will consider three possible comparison time models depending on the relationship between similarity and attention (illustrated in Figure 3):
• Similarity Variant: The more similar two alternatives are on the attribute being attended to, the longer they are compared.
• Dissimilarity Variant: The more similar two alternatives are on the attribute being attended to, the less time they are compared.

• Independent Variant: The time spent on a comparison is independent of similarity. Attribute dependent comparison time for attention variants: Sample functions illustrating the dependence of comparison times on attribute differences. In the independent attention variant (blue), attention time does not depend on attributes. In the similarity attention variant (black), more similar alternatives are compared for longer times. In the dissimilarity variant, more distinct alternatives are compared for longer times. The dashed gray line at the bottom reflects that most cases will include a minimum comparison time. For the similarity models we use a function of the shape exp(−λ|x a i − x a j |) where x a i is the value of alternative i on attribute a. For the dissimilarity model, we use a function of the form log(1 + λ|x a i − x a j |). These are convenient functions with the appropriate shape (i.e., they are both monotonic and saturate).

div.head: Psychological Plausibility of Similarity-based Attention
div.p: There is growing evidence that similarity-based attention mechanisms may play a role in multi-alternative decision-making. Rather than evaluating each option in isolation, decision-makers appear to allocate attention selectively, often in ways that reflect the similarity structure of the choice environment.

Empirical support for similarity-based attention comes from eye-tracking studies of multi-attribute choice. This research shows that people tend to fixate more often on alternatives that have similar attribute values, suggesting that attention is systematically drawn to similar options (Noguchi & Stewart, 2014;Russo & Rosen, 1975). Noguchi and Stewart (2014), for example, found that during decisions involving classic context effects, eye-fixation transitions occurred most frequently between the most similar alternatives. This pattern implies that similarity helps structure attentional shifts during deliberation. Likewise, Russo and Rosen (1975) analyzed eye movements as participants chose among six cars. They found that participants often made pairwise comparisons organized around similarity relations -such as two cars sharing the same make. These findings suggest that similarity facilitates direct comparisons in multi-attribute decision tasks.

Theoretical models have also incorporated similarity-based mechanisms into their accounts of attention and evidence accumulation. For example, multialternative decision by sampling (Noguchi & Stewart, 2018) proposes that the probability of evaluating an option on a given attribute increases with the similarity between its value and other values currently held in working memory. Likewise, the MLBA model (Trueblood et al., 2014) includes mechanisms whereby similarity between alternatives affects the allocation of attentional weights to attributes.
While these models differ in implementation, they share the assumption that similarity among alternatives can influence how information is attended to and used in the construction of preferences.

Related findings in visual attention research also support the plausibility of similarity-guided attention. For example, studies of pattern recognition have found that as the similarity between targets and non-targets increases, both the number and duration of eye fixations tend to increase, suggesting greater attentional demand when differentiating between similar stimuli (Gould, 1967). Additional evidence comes from research on object-based attention. In these paradigms, attention spreads across an entire object rather than being confined to a single spatial location. Egly et al. (1994) demonstrated that participants respond more quickly to targets that appear within the same object as a spatial cue, even when the target is not located at the cued position. The strength of this effect depends on the similarity between objects, with stronger cueing effects observed when objects are more dissimilar in features such as color or shape (Hein et al., 2017;Shomstein & Behrmann, 2008). Dissimilarity may enhance object individuation, making the boundaries between objects more distinct and, thereby, strengthening within-object attentional selection. Although situated within the domain of visual attention, these findings support the broader idea that similarity influences how attention is organized.

Together, these findings demonstrate that similarity shapes attentional processing across both perceptual and decision-making domains. Incorporating similarity-based attention into our modeling framework is therefore both theoretically and empirically grounded.

div.head: Impact of Similarity-based Attention on Context Effects
div.p: To assess the impact of these different similarity-based attention assumptions, we performed a simulation study to explore the presence of context effects in the three-alternative, two-attribute choice domain. To do so, we fixed two alternatives that differ on each attribute but fall along the line of indifference (0.4, 0.6), (0.6, 0.4) and varied the location of a third "decoy" alternative throughout attribute space. For each decoy location, we calculated the relative share of alternative x defined as n(x)/(n(x) + n(y)) where n(x) and n(y) are the number of times x and y are chosen. We subjected three models, corresponding to the three comparison time scenarios above, to this in silico experiment. For the similarity variant, we assumed the comparison time distribution for an alternative is exponential with a mean time of τ c n = exp(−λ|x a i − x a j |). This particular functional form was inspired by Shepard's (1987) law of generalization which defines similarity as an exponentially decaying function of distance. The MLBA model of context effects also employed an exponential similarity function (Trueblood et al., 2014), drawing inspiration from the work of Shepard. For the dissimilarity variant, we used τ c n = log(1 + λ|x a i − x a j |). The independent variant does not require a parameter to describe comparison times. For this model, the mean time spent on each comparison will be the same and thus the relative time spent on each comparison is a fixed number independent of attribute values. In the similarity and dissimilarity variants, λ is a scale parameter that determines how sensitive the comparison time is to attribute differences. Figure 4 shows that with no additional assumptions, the similarity variant demonstrates all three context effects. For example, when an attraction decoy is located at (0.35, 0.55), the relative choice share of x = 0.74. When a compromise decoy is located at (0.05, 0.95), the relative choice share of x = 0.58. Finally, when a similarity effect decoy is located at (0.65, 0.35), the relative choice share of x = 0.57. We note that it appears that in these simulations the attraction effect is stronger than the compromise and similarity effects. Dumbalska et al. (2020) created a decoy plane plot using human data and found that the attraction effect was empirically stronger than the compromise and similarity effects (see Figure 3A in their paper). However, we caution the reader about drawing conclusions regarding the relative strength of the three effects. More empirical work is needed on this topic. We also note that these simulations use stylized stimuli, a single set of parameters, and are only intended to convey general patterns. Since we did not fit data in the generation of Figure 4, mismatches between these simulations and data are to be expected. Context effects simulation study: To study the effect of adding a decoy alternative to a binary choice, we fix the attribute values of two alternatives (x and y shown on the plot) and vary the location of a third "decoy" alternative. For each decoy value, N = 1000 simulations are run and the number of times each alternative (n(x), n(y), n(d)) is chosen (as determined by the preference accumulation process defined in equation 2) is recorded. Each plot shows the relative share of alternative x as a function of decoy location (n(x)/n(x) + n(y)). The indicated regions on the similarity variant demonstrate it simultaneously accounts for the three classic context effects. For these simulations, we use an attention parameter λ = 5 and threshold b = 0.2.

Given the relative simplicity of this model (only two free parameters, λ and the accumulation threshold b), we next sought to understand how these three effects manifest in the similarity variant. It is natural to expect that the alternative with the highest average rate of preference accumulation will be chosen more often. To quantify this, we simulated the model 1,000 times stochastically with example attraction, compromise, and similarity decoys. We then averaged the stochastic trajectories over time and plotted these averages as a function of time ( Figure 5). In the attraction decoy case, the rate of preference accumulation (seen in the slope) for the target is highest, leading to it being chosen more often. The essential reason for this is that with similarity-based attention (using an exponential function for similarity and λ = 5), proximity of the decoy to the target in attribute space leads to an increase in the time spent on target favorable comparisons, leading to the target being selected more often.

The similarity and compromise effect scenarios however show that the mean evidence traces are flat for all three alternatives. In retrospect, this is sensible since all three alternatives lie on the line of indifference (see Figure 1). For every comparison that is favorable for one alternative, there is an equal and opposite comparison on the other attribute that is equally unfavorable. This leads to a net zero accumulation when averaged over many simulated model choices.

However, this is an average effect. Even when all options are on the line of indifference, random fluctuations in preference accumulation can lead to threshold crossing and a resulting choice. If the structure of this randomness is different for one of the alternatives, that could break this symmetry. To assess this, we next plotted the variance in accumulator traces. For each point in time we calculated the variance of the accumulation traces across all N=1,000 simulations ( Figure 5 bottom). Results demonstrate that in the similarity and compromise effect scenarios, the target exhibits more variability, which breaks the symmetry between the three otherwise equal alternatives. Since the first passage time of a purely diffusive process to a boundary inversely depends on the rate of diffusion (quantified by the slope of the plotted variance here), the target is chosen more frequently in both cases.
What is the interpretation of this explanation of the compromise and similarity effects?

On average, none of these alternatives is objectively superior and thus there is no net accumulation of evidence when aggregated over many simulated choices. However, the attention process introduces intra-trial variability in the length and sequence of attention segments and therefore accumulation. Due to this variability, it is more likely that a random sequence of comparisons favoring the target will occur. This leads to it being chosen more often even in the absence of average favorability.

We next assessed the influence of the critical similarity parameter λ on these results. The attraction effect is a consequence of the mean rate of accumulation (slope) of the target being greater than that of the competitor. Thus, we quantified the difference between the slopes of the mean lines in Figure 5 for the target and competitor (T-C). Figure 6 illustrates the difference in the mean rates of accumulation as a function of λ (top three panels). A positive difference indicates that the target has a higher mean rate of accumulation and thus is favored. These results show that the target exhibits a higher mean rate of accumulation for a range of λ values, consistent with results from Figure 5. Similarly, the target and competitor have the same mean rate of accumulation for all λ values in the similarity and compromise cases.

We similarly quantified the slopes of the average variance traces as a function of λ. Recall that a higher variance will tend to increase the likelihood of a threshold crossing for a given alternative. Thus, we compared the slope of the variance traces for the target and competitor (T-C), as shown in the lower panels of Figure 6. Consistent with Figure 5, for the similarity and compromise effects, the variance of the target accumulator is higher than the competitor for a range of λ values. This effect is reduced at larger λ values. We hypothesize that this is a consequence of the decreasing duration of comparisons for large λ values, which reduces the magnitude of the trial-to-trial variation responsible for this increased variance.

In synopsis, the emergence of the attraction effect from this model is a result of the similarity function differentially increasing the rate of preference accumulation for the target. This is a deterministic effect. The appearance of the similarity and compromise effects are however a result of the stochastic nature of the model. In these cases, no alternative is preferred by the model. However, the interaction of the similarity based Markov process with the stochastic accumulation process leads to stochastic patterns of attention that increase the likelihood of the target being chosen in those cases.

div.head: Figure 5
div.p: Similarity variant temporal evidence accumulation properties: To understand the genesis of context effects in the similarity variant, we track the evidence accumulation mean and variance over time for three choice sets indicative of the three context effects. To do so, we simulate 1000 independent trials for each choice set and quantify the mean and variance of the evidence state for each choice at each time (illustrated in the respective panels). For all simulations the attention parameter is λ = 5. No threshold parameter is included since only preference traces are quantified, not choices. The notation T,C, D is used here since the respective alternatives are the target, competitor, and decoy for these choice sets. Comparable figures for the independent and dissimilarity models are in the Supplemental Materials.

div.head: Additional Attention Factors
div.p: We next illustrate how other attention processes can be incorporated into the comparison transition component of the framework (the matrix Q), which is independent of the comparison time T process just discussed. In anticipation of subsequent modeling and analysis, we discuss two factors that may influence which comparisons are chosen more or less frequently. The first is attribute preference. When multiple attributes are present, it is conceivable and even likely that in many cases attributes will be given different weights in the decision process. One way to incorporate this is through the comparison transition matrix Q. For simplicity, we will assume Accumulator mean and variance slopes as a function of λ: Here we quantify the accumulator mean and variance effect seen in Figure 5 as a function of λ. All parameters and values of the target, competitor, and decoy are the same as in Figure 5. The value of the similarity strength parameter λ is varied. For each value, we simulate 1000 independent trials and quantify the mean and variance of the traces as a function of time (see Figure 5). Since these traces are linear, we quantify the slope of mean and variance traces for the target and competitor. Those slopes are then subtracted (target -competitor) to quantify the difference in mean slopes and separately the difference in variance slopes as a function of λ. Red vertical lines indicate the value of λ used for simulations in Figure 5.

two attributes here and introduce the parameter w encoding the weight for attribute 1 (and consequently 1 − w is the weight for attribute 2). Multiplying all elements of the matrix Q corresponding to attribute 1 by w (and similarly for attribute 2) naturally incorporates differential preference for attending to these attributes.

Spatial attention, arising from the presentation structure of information, is another factor that may influence decisions. For example, alternatives in different sections of a computer screen (e.g., left versus right) may receive greater attention and the comparison of physically adjacent alternatives may be more frequent. These factors can be readily incorporated into this framework through Q as well. We demonstrate this for one scenario, where comparisons of alternatives that are physically adjacent to each other are more common than those separated. Consider the three-alternative, two-attribute scenario. Assume the alternatives are ordered left (L), middle (M), and right (R) when presented. There are three spatial pairs of comparison here (LM, LR, RM).

We can define two parameters p LM , p MR indicating the probability of two of those comparisons occurring (with the third being 1 − p LM − p MR ). Combined with the aforementioned attribute weight w, this yields a three parameter model of spatial attention along with attribute preference that can be encoded in the transition matrix Q.

div.head: Similarity-based Attention Experiments
div.p: Our modeling framework predicts that similarity-based and dissimilarity-based attention can lead to different patterns of choices. To further explore the differences between these two attention mechanisms, we conducted simulations calculating the difference in the RST (see equation 1; Berkowitsch et al., 2014) between the similarity and dissimilarity model variants. For each of the three context effects, we created 1000 sets of simulations. Similar to the simulations shown in Figures 4 and 5 we fixed two alternatives at (0.4, 0.6) and (0.6, 0.4) for all simulations.
Then, for each simulation, we selected a decoy value in the appropriate ranges for the effect.
For the attraction decoy, we randomly selected attribute values from the ranges [0.2, 0.4] and [0.4 ,0.6]. The way these values were assigned depended on the alternative we were targeting.

When the target was (0.4, 0.6), we used the first range [0.2, 0.4] for attribute 1 and the second range [0.4, 0.6] for attribute 2. When the target was (0.6, 0.4), we reversed this: we used [0.4, 0.6] for attribute 1 and [0.2, 0.4] for attribute 2. For the compromise decoy, we randomly selected one attribute value from the range [0.1, 0.3]. When the target was (0.4, 0.6), this value was assigned as attribute 1. When the target was (0.6, 0.4), this value was assigned as attribute 2. The remaining attribute was calculated by subtracting 1 from the selected value. For the similarity decoy, we randomly selected one attribute value from the range [0.6, 0.65]. When the target was (0.4, 0.6), this value was assigned as attribute 1. When the target was (0.6, 0.4), this value was assigned as attribute 2. The remaining attribute was calculated by subtracting 1 from the selected value.

Next, we selected an attribute weight parameter in the range 0.3 < w < 0.7. Finally, we selected attention parameters in the range 1 < λ < 20 for the similarity and dissimilarity model variants. For each of the 1000 simulations, we simulated 10,000 choices for the two model variants and computed RST similarity − RST dissimilarity . Figure 7 visualizes the results by plotting a histogram of the differences for each effect.

As shown in the figure, the distribution of differences is almost entirely above zero for the attraction and compromise effects. This implies that the model framework almost always predicts a larger RST value under a similarity-based attention mechanism as compared to a dissimilarity-based attention mechanism for these two effects. This is consistent with previous simulations (see Figure 4) showing that a similarity-based attention mechanism can produce the attraction and compromise effects whereas a dissimilarity-based attention mechanism can lead to null or reserved attraction and compromise effects. The distribution of differences for the similarity effect is skewed left and centered just below zero. This implies that for the similarity effect, the model framework predicts either no difference in RST values between model variants or a larger RST value for dissimilarity-based attention as compared to similarity-based attention.

div.head: Figure 7
div.p: Simulation study comparing similarity-based and dissimilarity-based attention mechanisms: Individual plots show the difference in RST values simulated from the similarity model variant and dissimilarity model variant for the three context effects.

In the following sections, we present three behavioral experiments that were aimed at testing the model-based predictions shown in Figure 7 for the attraction, compromise, and similarity effects. Each experiment involved choices between three alternatives with two attributes. We manipulated similarity-based and dissimilarity-based attention by asking participants to identify the pair of options with the most similar attribute values (similarity condition) or the least similar attribute values (dissimilarity condition) before making a choice.

Our primary focus is on the difference between similarity and dissimilarity attention conditions instead of the presence and absence of the three effects. There are many other factors that can influence the existence of context effects, such as the spatial arrangement of options (as discussed in a later section and in Hasan et al. (2023) and the commensurability of attributes (Hayes et al., 2024). Thus, the cleanest test of similarity-based and dissimilarity-based attention is to directly compare RST values in conditions attempting to manipulate the two forms of attention. However, for each effect, we also provide information on RST values from the two attention conditions separately and note when these are consistent with the model simulations shown in Figure 4.

div.head: Transparency and openness
div.p: For Experiments 1-3, we report how we determined our sample size, all data exclusions (if any), all manipulations, and all measures in the study. All data and materials are available on the Open Science Framework (OSF) at https://osf.io/5y7mp/?view_only=1e998c595e3840a9802e1b8a95004fe0. Data were analyzed using the python package PyMC3 (Salvatier et al., 2016). This study's design and its analysis were pre-registered on OSF at https://osf.io/9bufg.

div.head: Participants
div.p: As described in the pre-registration, we targeted a sample size of approximately 300 participants with half of the participants in the similarity-based attention condition and the other half of participants in the dissimilarity-based attention condition. The sample size was based on the sample size and power analysis of the attraction effect from Hasan et al. (2023). 291 participants (male = 173, female = 115, non-binary = 2, unreported = 1; age: M = 42.94 , SD = 12.02) recruited via Amazon Mechanical Turk using the CloudResearch platform completed the experiment, which was approved by the Institutional Review Board (IRB) at Indiana University (#16178). N = 149 were randomly assigned to the similarity condition and N = 142 were assigned to the dissimilarity condition. One participant was excluded from the similarity condition due to a computer error which impacted their data file. The data were analyzed only after all data had been collected. All participants were compensated $1.00 for the completion of the study.

div.head: Materials
div.p: Participants were asked to make investment decisions about businesses, based upon ratings from two financial advisors. Ratings ranged between 0 to 100 with 0 implying a very low likelihood of a good return on investment (ROI) and 100 indicating a very high likelihood of a good ROI. The attribute values of each option were based on those used in Trueblood (2012).

Four types of businesses were used to examine the attraction effect: two focal options (X and Y ) and two attraction decoys (A x and A y ). The two decoy options were similar, but inferior to their associated focal option (e.g., A x was similar, but inferior to X). In addition to choice sets examining the attraction effect, the experiment also included filler choice sets where there was a clearly superior option (i.e., a business that dominated the others on both attributes). In total, there were 10 attraction effect trials with the A x decoy, 10 attraction effect trials with the A y decoy, and 10 filler trials. For the attraction effect trials, the specific attribute values for each option varied slightly across trials. The mean and standard deviation of the attribute values for the attraction effect options are provided in Table 1. The full list of stimuli are available on OSF.

div.head: Procedures
div.p: To examine the effect of similarity-based and dissimilarity-based attention mechanisms on context effects, participants were randomly assigned to one of two between-subject conditions (similarity or dissimilarity) at the beginning of the experiment.

At the start of the experiment, participants were told that they would be making investment decisions about businesses. They were told that on each trial, they would see three different businesses and to select the one that they would like to invest in. They were also told that they would be given ratings from two financial advisors. The ratings were described to participants as providing the likelihood of a good return on investment (ROI), with a rating of 0 implying a very low likelihood of a good ROI and a rating of 100 implying a very high likelihood of a good ROI.

Additionally, participants were told that the evaluations of businesses can vary from advisor to advisor. Thus, two different financial advisors can provide different ratings. Participants were told to treat the ratings from both advisors equally. The full set of instructions are available on OSF.

At the beginning of each trial, participants were presented with three businesses and their ROI ratings from two advisors (Figure 8). For example, on trials testing the attraction effect, the three businesses consisted of the focal options X and Y and a decoy option (either A x or A y ). The options and their attributes were displayed in a table with the different options in different rows and the two attributes in separate columns. The row locations of the options were randomized.

Before making their choice on each trial, all participants completed a similarity judgment task (see Figure 8 for an example). In the similarity condition, participants were asked to identify the pair of options having the most similar values on each attribute, separately. First, they were queried about attribute 1 (i.e., Advisor 1) followed by attribute 2 (i.e., Advisor 2). Participants received feedback following each judgment. After both judgments, the participants selected the business they preferred (Figure 8). In the dissimilarity condition, participants were asked to identify the pair of options having the most dissimilar values on each attribute prior to the investment decisions. Similar to the similarity condition, participants were asked about attribute 1 before attribute 2 and received feedback on each judgment. After participants made their pairwise

div.head: Figure 8
div.p: Example of a trial in Experiments 1-3. On a given trial, participants first judged the similarity (or dissimilarity) of the options along attribute 1. Next, they judged the similarity (or dissimilarity) of the options along attribute 2. Finally, they made a decision about their preferred investment. After their choice, the participants proceeded to the next trial. An example of an attraction effect trial in the similarity condition is shown. similarity/dissimilarity judgment, the attribute values of the correct pair of options were shown in bold font and the font size of these values increased from 30 px to 45 px. Thus, the most similar/dissimilar options were shown in large, bold font when participants were making their investment decision. After making their decision, participants proceeded to the next trial.
Participants did not receive feedback about their decision. The order of the trials was fully randomized.

div.head: Results
div.p: No participants were excluded from the analyses. We also note that the filler trials were removed from these analyses. We used a hierarchical Bayesian model to estimate the difference in RST values (equation 1; Berkowitsch et al., 2014) between the similarity and dissimilarity conditions. The model estimates the RST for each condition separately as well as the difference in RST values between conditions. An analysis using a modified version of RST (Katsimpokis et al., 2023) yielded nearly identical results and is provided in the Supplemental Materials.

The model we used is an extension of the one used in Trueblood (2015) and Trueblood et al. (2015). It is a beta-binomial model where the number of times the target is selected follows a binomial distribution: Binomial(θ, n), where θ represents the probability that the target is selected and n is the number of times the target plus the competitor are selected. We estimated a separate θ parameter for each person. We also assumed that the person-specific θ parameters were drawn from population-level beta distributions with mean (µ) and concentration (κ) parameters.

We allowed for separate µ and κ parameters for the similarity and dissimilarity conditions. The priors for the hyper-parameters were set to be relatively vague, with µ ∼ Beta(1, 1) and κ ∼ |N(0, 10)|. The model also estimates the difference between conditions as δ = µ similarity − µ dissimilarity . See the Supplemental Materials for the graphical model. The model was fit using the python package PyMC3 (Salvatier et al., 2016). Four Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) chains with 5000 samples each were used to estimate the posterior distributions. All chains converged with R-hat values less than 1.1. Table 2 shows the posterior mean and the 95% highest posterior density (HPD) interval for δ and the µ parameters for each condition. For δ, if the HPD interval is above 0, that suggests the similarity condition produced a larger RST value than the dissimilarity condition. If the HPD interval for µ is above 0.5, that suggests the target was selected more than the competitor, indicating an attraction effect. Likewise, if the HPD interval for µ is below 0.5, that suggests the competitor is selected more than the target, indicating a reverse attraction effect. As shown in the table, δ is positive and the HPD interval does not include zero. This shows that the similarity condition produced a larger RST value than the dissimilarity condition, in line with our model simulations shown in Figure 7. Further, an attraction effect is observed in the similarity condition, and a reverse attraction effect is observed in the dissimilarity condition. In both cases, the HPD interval excludes 0.5. These results are illustrated in Figure 9 and are in line with the model simulations shown in Figure 4.

As described in the pre-registration, we also analyzed the data using only those participants who achieved at least 60% accuracy in selecting the most similar (dissimilar) attributes in the first part of each trial. As shown in the Supplementary Materials, the results are unchanged. Further, the difference (δ) is larger when restricting the analyses to those with high accuracy in detecting similar (dissimilar) attributes. This is in line with our prediction that increased attention to similar (dissimilar) options modulates the RST value.

div.head: Attraction Effect Similarity Effect Compromise Effect
Figure 9
div.p: Behavioral results for Experiments 1-3: The relative choice share of the target for two conditions where attention was directed either towards similar options or dissimilar options for three context effects: attraction (Experiment 1), similarity (Experiment 2), and compromise (Experiment 3). Bars show the mean RST, error bars show the 95% confidence interval, and grey dots show the individual RST values.

div.head: Participants
div.p: Similar to Experiment 1 and as described in the pre-registration, we aimed for a sample size of around 300 participants, split between the similarity-based and dissimilarity-based attention conditions. 297 participants (male = 134, female = 159, non-binary = 2, genderqueer = 1, unreported = 1; age: M = 44.19 , SD = 13.06) recruited via Amazon Mechanical Turk using the CloudResearch platform completed the experiment, which was approved by the IRB at Indiana University (#16178). N = 147 were randomly assigned to the similarity condition and N = 150

were assigned to the dissimilarity condition. One participant was excluded from the similarity condition due to a computer error which impacted their data file. Data analysis began after all data were collected, and participants received $1.00 for completing the study.

div.head: Materials
div.p: Similar to Experiment 1, participants were asked to choose their preferred business based on the ROI ratings from two financial advisors. There were four options used to examine the similarity effect: two focal options and two similarity decoys (S x and S y ). Like Experiment 1, this experiment also included filler choice sets where there was a clearly superior option. In total, there were 10 similarity effect trials with the S x decoy, 10 similarity effect trials with the S y decoy, and 10 filler trials. For the similarity effect trials, the specific attribute values for each option varied slightly across trials. The mean and standard deviation of the attribute values for the similarity effect options are provided in Table 3 and are identical to those used in Trueblood (2012).

div.head: Procedures
div.p: The procedure for Experiment 2 was identical to Experiment 1. Participants were randomly assigned to either the similarity or dissimilarity condition at the beginning of the experiment, and then completed 30 randomized trials. On each trial, participants started with attribute-wise similarity/dissimilarity judgments about the businesses based on their assigned condition. After making these judgments, participants selected the business that they preferred and then proceeded to the next trial.

div.head: Results
div.p: No participants were excluded from the analyses. Similar to Experiment 1, we used a hierarchical Bayesian model to estimate the difference in RST values between the Table 2 shows the posterior mean and the 95% HPD interval for δ and the two µ parameters. As shown in the table, the HPD interval for δ is below 0, suggesting that the dissimilarity-based attention condition produced a larger RST value than the similarity-based attention condition. This result is consistent with the model simulations shown in Figure 7.

Additionally, we observe a similarity effect (i.e., RST > 0.5) in the dissimilarity-based attention condition and a weak reverse similarity effect (i.e., RST < 0.5) in the similarity-based attention condition (see Figure 9).

In the Supplemental Materials, we also analyzed the data using only those participants who achieved at least 60% accuracy in selecting the most similar (dissimilar) attributes in the first part of each trial. The results are unchanged after exclusions. Additionally, the difference (δ) is larger when restricting the analyses to those with high accuracy in detecting similar (dissimilar) attributes, consistent with our prediction that increased attention to similar (dissimilar) options modulates the RST value. to the similarity condition and N = 149 were assigned to the dissimilarity condition. Two participants were excluded from the similarity condition due to a computer error that impacted their data file. Data analysis began after all data were collected, and participants received $1.00
for completing the study.

div.head: Materials
div.p: Similar to Experiments 1 and 2, participants in Experiment 3 made investment decisions based on the ROI ratings from two financial advisors. There were four options used to examine the compromise effect: two focal options and two compromise decoys (C x and C y ). Like the other experiments, Experiment 3 also included filler choice sets where there was a clearly superior option. In total, there were 10 compromise effect trials with the C x decoy, 10 compromise effect trials with the C y decoy, and 10 filler trials. For the compromise effect trials, the specific attribute values for each option varied slightly across trials. The mean and standard deviation of the attribute values for the compromise effect options are provided in Table 4. Note that the distance between the compromise decoy and the target is 2-units less than the distance between the target and competitor, so that the answer to the similarity ratings is unique on each trial.

div.head: Procedures
div.p: The procedure for Experiment 3 was identical to Experiments 1 and 2. Participants were randomly assigned to either the similarity-based or dissimilarity-based attention condition at the beginning of the experiment, and then completed 30 randomized trials. On each trial, participants first made two attribute-wise similarity/dissimilarity judgments based on their condition, and then they selected their preferred business.

div.head: Results
div.p: No participants were excluded from the analyses. Similar to Experiments 1 and 2, we used a hierarchical Bayesian model to estimate the difference in RST values between the similarity-based and dissimilarity-based attention conditions and to test for the presence of the compromise effect in each condition. The approach and model specifications were identical to Experiments 1 and 2. An analysis using a modified version of RST (Katsimpokis et al., 2023) yielded nearly identical results (see Supplemental Materials). Table 2 shows the posterior mean and the 95% HPD interval for δ and the two µ parameters. As shown in the table, the HPD interval for δ is above 0, suggesting that the similarity-based attention condition produced a larger RST value than the dissimilarity-based attention condition, consistent with the model simulations shown in Figure 7. Additionally, we observe a compromise effect (i.e., RST > 0.5) in the similarity-based attention condition and a null effect (i.e., RST ≈ 0.5) in the dissimilarity-based attention condition (see Figure 9).

As in Experiments 1 and 2, we also analyzed the data using only those participants who achieved at least 60% accuracy in selecting the most similar (dissimilar) attributes in the first part of each trial. The results are unchanged after exclusions (see Supplemental Material). Similar to Experiments 1 and 2, the difference (δ) is larger when restricting the analyses to those with high accuracy in detecting similar (dissimilar) attributes.

div.head: Discussion of Experiments 1-3
div.p: Experiments 1-3 examined differences between similarity-based and dissimilarity-based attention for the attraction, similarity, and compromise effects. We observed that by encouraging participants to attend to similar versus dissimilar options, we can modulate the proportion of times participants selected the target over the competitor, as measured by the RST. Further, the changes we observed in the behavioral data follow the model predictions shown in Figure 7.

Additionally, the pattern of context effects we observed is generally in line with the model predictions shown in Figure 4. In the similarity-based attention condition, we observed strong attraction and compromise effects and a weak reverse similarity effect. The similarity model variant (right panel in Figure 4) also predicts the presence of the attraction and compromise effects. This model can also produce the similarity effect, but only for a narrow range of similarity decoys. As shown in the figure, the similarity decoy needs to be located very close to the competitor in order for the effect to arise. It is possible that our lack of a similarity effect in the behavioral data is related to the positioning of the decoy. In the dissimilarity-based attention condition, we observed a reverse attraction effect, null compromise effect, and strong similarity effect. The dissimilarity model variant (middle panel in Figure 4) also predicts a reverse attraction effect and a strong similarity effect. Depending on the position of the decoy, the model predicts a reverse or null compromise effect.

Overall, we find the consistency between the behavioral and model simulation results compelling. We believe these results demonstrate that similarity-based and dissimilarity-based attention contributes to the elusive nature of context effects. In the next section, we explore the role of spatial attention and context effects.

Spatial Attention: Reanalysis of Trueblood et al. 2015 In Trueblood et al. (2015) the attraction, compromise, and similarity effects were examined using the perceptual paradigm developed in Trueblood et al. (2013) where participants made decisions about the size of rectangles. In addition to studying the three effects within participants, the Trueblood et al. (2015)

div.head: Transparency and openness
div.p: All data are available on the OSF at https://osf.io/5y7mp/?view_only=1e998c595e3840a9802e1b8a95004fe0. Data were analyzed using the python package PyMC3 (Salvatier et al., 2016). This study's analysis was not pre-registered.

div.head: Method
div.p: Seventy-five participants took part in the experiment in exchange for course credit. On each trial, participants were shown three rectangles and asked to choose the one with the largest area. The rectangles were solid black and appeared on a white background. The height and width of the rectangles were varied in order to generate choice sets for the attraction, compromise, and similarity effects (similar to attributes of price and quality in studies of context effects with consumer products). For each choice set, the two focal rectangles had equal area, but one rectangle had larger height and smaller width than the other. We note that much of the research on context effects uses stimuli with clearly separable attributes (e.g., price and quality). Previous research has shown that height and width of rectangles are perceived separately and then integrated to form area estimates (Anderson & Weiss, 1971).

Participants completed 720 trials: 160 with attraction effect choice sets, with similarity effect choice sets, 160 with compromise effect choice sets, and 240 filler trials where one rectangle was clearly the largest. For the context effects choice sets, half of the choice sets included a decoy targeting one of the two focal options and the other half of the choice sets included a decoy targeting the other focal option. The trials were fully randomized. The left to right placement of the options was also randomized, resulting in six distinct orders.

div.head: Results
div.p: No participants were excluded from the analyses. Similar to Experiments 1-3, we used a hierarchical Bayesian model to test for the presence of the three context effects across the six different orders. The model specifications were similar to Experiments 1-3. The graphical model is provided in the supplemental materials. The model was fit using PyMC3 (Salvatier et al., 2016). Four Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) chains with 5000 samples each were used to estimate the posterior distributions. All chains converged with R-hat values less than 1.1. Table 5 shows the posterior mean and the 95% HPD interval for the µ parameter, estimated separately for the three effects and six orders. Results show that for some spatial orders standard effects emerge, but for other orders, null or reversed effects occur (see both Table 5 and Figure 10). We hypothesize that the observed differences in RST values across the different orders reflect biases in spatial attention. In particular, we suggest that greater attention is allocated to adjacent options as compared to non-adjacent options. In particular, when the target is the middle option (i.e., CTD, DTC), it is adjacent to both the decoy and competitor. In this case, the target receives more attention and thus accumulates evidence faster than the other options, leading to standard context effects. Likewise, when the competitor is the middle option (i.e., TCD, DCT), it receives more attention, resulting in null or reversed context effects. In the remaining two cases (i.e., TDC, CDT), results are mixed.

For TDC, all three standard effects occur. However, for CDT, only a standard similarity effect occurs. We believe the difference here is the left versus right placement of the target. When the target is placed in the leftmost position, we believe it receives enhanced attention because English (the primary language of our participants) is a left-to-right writing system. For the model, we simulated synthetic data from the similarity attention variant accounting for effects of spatial location of the alternatives on attention. Specifically, we assumed that comparison of adjacent alternatives is ∼ 2.5 times more likely than comparison of non-adjacent alternatives. The alternative attribute values were in each case T = (0.4, 0.6), C = (0.6, 0.4) with D A = (0.3, 0.5), D C = (0.2, 0.8), D S = (0.55, 0.45). For the parameters, the attribute weight was w = 0.5, the threshold b = 0.2 and the attention parameter was λ = 2.5 for the attraction and similarity effects and λ = 7.5 for the compromise effect.

To further examine the impact of spatial attention biases on context effects, we performed a model simulation exercise using the similarity model variant. For these simulations, we allowed for the effects of spatial location on attention allocation. In particular, we assumed that the comparison of adjacent options is ∼ 2.5 times more likely than comparison of non-adjacent options. For these simulations, we used artificial stimuli values, not stimuli values from the task.

Our goal here is to simply show that the modeling framework can qualitatively produce the observed behavioral patterns. In a later section, we quantitatively fit and evaluate the modeling framework using this data. The attribute values for the simulations were T = (0.4, 0.6), C = (0.6, 0.4) with D A = (0.3, 0.5), D S = (0.55, 0.45), D C = (0.2, 0.8), where D A , D S , and D C are the decoys for the attraction, similarity, and compromise effects respectively. In these simulations, we fixed the attribute weight at w = 0.5, the threshold at b = 0.2 and the attention parameter at λ = 2.5 for the attraction and similarity effects and λ = 7.5 for the compromise effect (a larger value of λ more robustly produces the compromise effect).

The general qualitative pattern from the model is similar to the data. In particular, we observe standard effects when the target is the middle option and reversed / null effects when the competitor is the middle option. We also note that there are discrepancies between the model simulations and data. This suggests there are aspects of the data the model simulations fail to capture. However, the simple spatial attention process does appear to capture the gross pattern that the target gets a boost when it is the middle option.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The reanalysis of Trueblood et al. (2015) revealed that the display layout of options had a large impact on the presence / absence of context effects. We hypothesized that changes in display layout might impact how attention is allocated in the task and thus alter context effects.

To this end, we conducted model simulations examining how biases in spatial attention influence context effects. The modeling results were qualitatively consistent with the behavioral findings, suggesting that simple biases in attention can have large impacts on choice behavior.

div.head: Quantitative Evaluation of the Modeling Framework
div.p: To further evaluate the importance and influence of similarity and spatial based attention factors in these decisions, we quantitatively fit four versions of this model to the full choice-RT data from Trueblood et al. (2015). We toggle similarity and spatial factors in and out of the framework (resulting in four models). For the similarity factor, we used the same exponential dependence of deliberation time on similarity; more similar comparisons are compared for longer duration. When this factor is not included, all comparisons are distributed equally (i.e., independent model variant).

For spatial attention, we included two additional parameters (p LM , p RM ) that alter the weights for different comparisons. This accounts for potential biases for adjacent options and left versus right comparisons. When this factor is not present, all comparisons are equally probable.

The most extensive version of this model containing both factors has the following seven estimable parameters: threshold (b), attribute weight (w), non-decision time (t nd ), a drift rate scaling parameter (v scale ), the similarity decay parameter (λ), and the two spatial probability parameters (p LM , p RM ). The drift rate scaling parameter is a methodological parameter that converts attribute units into the preference domain. This is necessary for mathematical consistency (the left and right side of the preference updating equation must have the same units) and is discussed further in the Supplemental Materials. The simplest version of the model that omits both factors contains only four parameters (b, w,t nd , v scale ). We also note that we use the log of the attribute values (i.e., height and width) to handle the fact that height and width multiplicatively contribute to the area.

div.head: Continuous model extension and model fitting procedure
div.p: The fully stochastic version of this model can in principle be fit to choice-RT data using simulation based methods such as the Probability Density Approximation (PDA) method (Holmes, 2015;Holmes and Trueblood, 2018;Holmes et al., 2016). This is computationally cumbersome however. We thus develop a continuous approximation to this model that utilizes stochastic differential equations in place of full stochastic simulations. Full details of the description, derivation, and validation of this are in the Supplementary Materials. We briefly note however that this approximation is theoretically grounded. It is essentially the asymptotic limit that results from taking the simulation time step in the stochastic model ∆T → 0.
The end result of this approximation is a model of the form
div.formula: d ⃗ P = v scale * ⃗ vdt +⃗ σd⃗ w,(7)
div.p: where P is a time varying vector of preferences, ⃗ v is a vector of accumulation rates, ⃗ σ is a vector of variances, and v scale is the previously mentioned methodological scaling parameter. Note that This approximation to the stochastic model is an independent race (IR) to threshold model. That is, it is three stochastic accumulators independently racing to the choice threshold,

where the first one to reach that threshold is the chosen alternative. The significant benefit of this simplification is that IR models have known, analytically solvable choice-RT distributions based on the Wald / Inverse Gaussian distribution (see Supplemental Materials). This dramatically simplifies the choice-RT fitting process without sacrificing any of the core characteristics of the modeling framework.

To fit this model, we use a Bayesian approach to fit full choice-RT data, accounting for the spatial order of presented alternatives. Following prior studies, we use Differential Evolution MCMC (DEMC) (Turner et al., 2013). Prior to fitting these models, parameter recovery was demonstrated (Supplemental Materials) using the same experimental design and stimuli as the experiment itself. Figure 11 illustrates the quality of fit for the four model variants by comparing choice proportions and mean RTs derived from the posterior mean parameter sets for each individual with those from data. Results illustrate that both similarity and spatial attention factors are needed to provide a reasonable account of the data. When only one attention factor is present, the model performs quantitatively worse. More importantly, the single factor models predict higher competitor than target choice proportions, which is qualitatively contrary to data.

div.head: Results
div.p: We further analyzed the distribution of participants' posterior mean parameter values for the model with both similarity and spatial attention included (Figure 12 attribute weight is generally close to 0.5, which is reasonable since the two attributes in question are length and width of rectangles. The similarity decay parameter λ is significantly different from 0. Finally, participants broadly show an adjacency bias, but not a substantial bias for comparisons involving left or right options.

div.head: General Discussion
div.p: Context effects in choice, particularly the attraction, compromise, and similarity effects, have received considerable attention over the last several decades. Yet despite being observed across multiple cognitive domains (Farmer et al., 2015(Farmer et al., , 2017Maylor & Roberts, 2007;Trueblood, 2012Trueblood, , 2015Trueblood et al., 2013;Wedell, 1991;Yearsley et al., 2021) and across multiple species (Bateson et al., 2003;Latty & Trueblood, 2020;Parrish et al., 2015;Shafir et al., 2002), they have proven to be simultaneously fragile (Spektor et al., 2021). In this paper, we introduced a novel modeling framework that explains the elusive nature of context effects. Using this framework, we demonstrate how the presence, absence, and reversal of classic context effects can be explained by variations in the attention process during evidence accumulation.

The idea that attention is important for understanding context effects is shared by most dynamic models of context effects (Trueblood, 2022). These models have, in many cases, assumed that alternatives are compared to each other in a pairwise fashion, that comparisons between more similar alternatives receive greater weight, and that all alternatives and attributes cannot be simultaneously attended to. Our work extends and generalizes these prior theories. Specifically, the framework described here assumes that only one comparison on one attribute can be attended to at any given time but that the sequence of comparisons is governed by a structured attention process. Rather than assume a fixed attention process (i.e. similarity-based), we explore a range of different attention processes and their consequences on choices. Results show that when more similar alternatives are compared for longer periods of time, the classic context effects arise. However, if that attention processes is altered (e.g., dissimilar alternative are compared for longer periods of time), the effects can disappear or reverse, as has been found in a number of recent empirical studies (Cataldo & Cohen, 2018, 2019Evans et al., 2021;Spektor et al., 2018).

Importantly, our framework also allows for intrinsic factors, such as an individual's attribute biases, and extrinsic factors, such as the spatial arrangement of options in the choice display, to enter into the attention process. In sum, our work illustrates that attentional dynamics are key to understanding why context effects can be simultaneously general and fragile.

We validated our modeling framework using a combination of behavioral experiments and a reanalysis of previously published data. Results from Experiments 1-3 showed that by simply encouraging participants to attend to similar versus dissimilar options, we were able to modulate the strength of the three effects in ways that were consistent with model predictions. To test whether attentional biases arising from the spatial layout of items may alter context effects, we reanalyzed data from Trueblood et al. (2015). In that study the attraction, similarity, and compromise effects occurred when the target was the middle option, whereas null or reverse effects occurred when the competitor was the middle option. Our results indicate this is a consequence of people's preference for comparing spatially adjacent options more than nonadjacent options. This result, in particular, illustrates how easily experimental factors can alter empirical findings. In summary, our findings illustrate the critical role of attention in the generation of context effects. Further, this modeling approach provides a way to disentangle different factors that may influence attention and their potential effects on observations.

div.head: Relationships to Other Modeling Approaches
div.p: Over the past several decades, a wide range of mathematical and computational models have been developed to account for context effects in multi-alternative, multi-attribute choice.

These models span disciplines including economics, marketing, psychology, and neuroscience. They include cognitive models that focus on the dynamic processes of decision-making (e.g., Roe et al., 2001), as well as rational models based on Bayesian belief updating (e.g., Rigoli et al., 2017).

Our modeling framework builds on ideas from previous cognitive models of context effects, particularly the idea that attention plays an important role in multi-alternative, multi-attribute choice (Trueblood, 2022). Although our goal was not to introduce a new model to test against others in a head-to-head comparison, it is informative to compare and contrast the present modeling approach with alternative theories.

div.head: Relationship to Dynamic Cognitive Models
div.p: Most dynamic cognitive models assume that individuals shift a window of attention throughout deliberation to evaluate various options. Here we highlight three models, MDFT (Roe et al., 2001), MLBA (Trueblood et al., 2014), and multialternative decision by sampling (MDbS; Noguchi and Stewart, 2018), to illustrate the relationship between the current framework and existing theories. We refer readers to Trueblood (2022) Additionally, both MDbS and MLBA incorporate some notion of similarity-based attention. In MDbS, the probability of evaluating the value of an option on a particular attribute is proportional to the similarity between that option's value and other values in working memory, including values retrieved from long-term memory (e.g., memory of prices from past experience).

In MLBA, the attention weight for each pairwise comparison depends on the similarity of the values being compared. The present framework allows for similarity to affect the amount of time spent on each comparison. For example, in the similarity model variant, greater similarity among options leads to longer deliberation time for the comparison of those options.

We also point out some key differences between the current framework and previous modeling approaches. The current framework is stochastic rather than ballistic as is the case for Another important distinction between our framework and past approaches is that we show that a single mechanism, namely similarity-based attention, is sufficient for producing the attraction, compromise, and similarity effects (see Figure 4). In other dynamic models, additional mechanisms are required to produce at least one of the three effects. For example, MDFT accounts for the attraction and compromise effects using distance-dependent lateral inhibition (Roe et al., 2001), MLBA accounts for all three effects using a combination of similarity-based attention and asymmetric weighting of advantages and disadvantages (Trueblood et al., 2014;Tsetsos et al., 2015), and MDbS accounts for the similarity effect by assuming that people tend to ignore relatively small differences (Noguchi & Stewart, 2018). Our results show that while these factors may be present, they are not necessary and attention alone can lead to the contextual sensitivities observed in the classic effects.

Notably, MDbS was shown to qualitatively account for a broader range of behavioral phenomena beyond the three classic context effects, including (but not limited to) the effects of previously experienced values on subsequent evaluations (Stewart et al., 2015;Ungemach et al., 2011), the negative impact of familiarity on the attraction and compromise effects (Kim & Hasher, 2005;Sheng et al., 2005), attribute alignability (Markman & Medin, 1995), attribute balance (Chernev, 2005), and attribute spacing effects (Cooke & Mellers, 1998) (see Table 4 in Noguchi and Stewart, 2018 for a full list). MDbS explains many of these phenomena through its assumption that previously experienced attribute values can be sampled from long-term memory and compared to the attribute values in the immediate choice context. For example, greater familiarity with the choice domain implies that decision makers have a larger sample of attributes that they can sample from memory, which will tend to "dilute" the impact of comparisons in the immediate context and thereby weaken the attraction and compromise effects (Noguchi & Stewart, 2018). Our modeling framework could be augmented to include comparisons with previously experienced outcomes, which would allow it to capture these effects as well. Other phenomena, such as the attribute balance effect, can be explained in both MDbS and the current framework by assuming that the choice presentation format influences the likelihood of attending to different types of comparisons (e.g., comparisons across attribute dimensions, which are assumed to drive the attribute balance effect in MDbS, should be more likely when the dimensions are commensurable; see Hayes et al., 2024). The simplicity and flexibility of our modeling framework makes it easy to incorporate additional assumptions and broaden the range of phenomena that it can explain.

Our framework explicitly models the attention process during deliberation. Gluth et al. (2024) also propose a model of how attention is allocated during multi-attribute choice. Their model provides a theory of how people search for additional information (i.e., attribute values) during deliberation. The model is implemented as a hierarchical Bayesian framework with a set of layers to represent belief distributions regarding attribute values, which subsequently serve as the foundation for belief distributions over the values of options. They apply their model to two alternative decisions where each alternative is described by multiple attributes. At the time of writing, the model does not account for context effects among three options.

Another approach is to use empirical measures of visual attention (i.e., gaze data) as input to the evidence accumulation process, as in the attentional drift diffusion model (aDDM;Krajbich et al., 2010). This approach is fundamentally different from the one proposed here: One makes a priori assumptions about the way in which attention fluctuates between different pieces of information and how it influences choice, while the other uses exogenous measures of visual attention to inform the model without explaining why gaze is allocated that way in the first place.

Only a few models have attempted to explain the allocation and timing of visual fixations during the deliberation process (for example, see Callaway et al., 2021;Gluth et al., 2024;Jang et al., 2021). The aDDM has proven to be quite useful as a tool for understanding the moderating effects of visual attention on value-based decision making (e.g., Fisher, 2017;Krajbich, 2018, 2019; for a review, see Krajbich, 2019). It does not however attempt to understand the process responsible for the allocation of attention. Recently, gaze-dependent evidence accumulation models have also been leveraged to study context effects in multi-alternative, multi-attribute choice (Molter et al., 2022). However, because attention is treated as an exogenous variable in the aDDM and other gaze-dependent models, the models make no predictions for the effect that different spatial layouts, for example, will have on attention and (consequently) decision making.

The behavior of these models depends on the eye movement data that gets fed into them. In contrast, the present framework allows us to incorporate different theories about the role of spatial and other presentation-related factors into the model's attention process in order to examine their predicted effects on choice behavior. In the Future Directions section, we return to the topic of eye-tracking measures and how they might be used to supplement our modeling framework.

div.head: Relationship to Rational Models
div.p: The modeling framework proposed here follows in the tradition of evidence-accumulation models (Ratcliff, 1978), which represent the temporal dynamics underlying choices. However, not all psychological models of context effects rely on dynamic or mechanistic processes. A second class of models stems from the tradition of rational analysis and Bayesian decision theory.

These models seek to explain context effects as rational responses to uncertainty or to the structure of the environment. Bayesian account in which the value of an option corresponds to a precision-weighted prediction error. This framework explains the three classic context effects as well as between-choice context effects (i.e., how past options impact current choices). A third approach by Howes et al. (2016) shows that the three context effects can be understood as expected value maximizing choices under noisy observations. In their model, context effects arise as optimal adaptations to limitations in perceptual and cognitive processing.

One key benefit of rational models is that they provide normative benchmarks for understanding behavior, showing how context effects can arise as optimal responses to uncertainty, limited information, or environmental structure. By grounding explanations in principles of Bayesian inference or expected utility maximization, these models can help clarify when seemingly irrational behaviors -such as preference reversals -may actually be adaptive.

This contrasts with cognitive models, which typically focus on the underlying mental processes and often require assumptions about attention, memory, or neural dynamics to account for the At present, we are not aware of any rational models that account for the elusive nature of context effects -specifically, why such effects sometimes appear, disappear, or even reverse. One particularly challenging case involves the influence of spatial arrangement on context effects, as highlighted in the reanalysis of Trueblood et al. (2015). It remains unclear how a purely rational framework would account for these spatial influences. In contrast, the modeling approach proposed here can capture these findings by incorporating psychologically plausible assumptions about how attention shapes the preference accumulation process. Developing rational models that can accommodate these complex patterns of behavior represent an important direction for future research.

div.head: An Alternative Explanation of the Elusiveness of Context Effects
div.p: Like other dynamic decision models, our theoretical framework relies on the integration and accumulation of relative comparisons during deliberation to explain the emergence of context effects (Busemeyer et al., 2019). Moreover, it uses attentional dynamics during the deliberation process to explain the elusiveness of context effects. An alternative explanation, suggested by Spektor et al. (2021), is that the elusiveness of context effects is due to noisiness in the subjective representation of the choice set. Certain features of the choice task, such as the presentation modality (e.g., graphical versus numerical) of the attributes, could make it more difficult for decision makers to obtain an accurate representation of the options. Spektor et al. suggest that when decision makers first encounter a choice, there is some degree of uncertainty or noise in the representation of the options. Although the uncertainty gradually diminishes over the course of deliberation, if the level of uncertainty is high, dominance relationships and attribute orderings will be more difficult to detect, inhibiting the attraction and compromise effects and potentially leading to reversals of these effects. On the other hand, the similarity effect is less likely to be impacted by representational noise because any difficulties in detecting dominance relationships would likely influence the competitor and decoy as opposed to the target. If the level of uncertainty is low, the attraction and compromise effects should not be impacted and standard effects are anticipated.

Currently, the idea of representational noise has not been incorporated into a formal model of context effects. Future work could explore whether it is possible to extend our framework to allow for uncertainty in the attribute values that changes over time (see for example, Lee and Daunizeau, 2021). We note that there are many ways of adding noise to models and care must be taken to make sure that the addition of noise does not result in model tractability issues. As of now, our framework explains the elusive nature of context effects purely through subtle changes in attention during the deliberation process, treating the attribute values as given.

div.head: Benefits of the Current Modeling Approach
div.p: We have stressed that our proposed model is a framework in the sense that it encompasses many possible model variants. For example, we showed how three different assumptions about the relationship between similarity and deliberation time could be incorporated into the framework.

Further, attribute biases and spatial attention mechanisms can be encoded in the conditional transition matrix that contains the probabilities of switching to different comparisons. A model variant in which comparisons between adjacent options are more probable than comparisons between nonadjacent options was able to account for spatial order effects present in previously published data (Trueblood et al., 2015). The flexibility of our modeling framework is one of its primary advantages, and there are many other possible modifications that could be made.

Another advantage of the current modeling framework is that it can be fit to choice-RT data and that its parameters are recoverable (see Supplemental Materials). This is important, as other dynamic models of context effects have been shown to have relatively poor parameter recovery (Evans et al., 2019). Complex models with many parameters often have strong parameter trade-offs, where increases in one parameter can be compensated by decreases in another (e.g., Miletić et al., 2017). When this occurs, the parameters are said to be weakly identified and it is no longer possible to reliably interpret the parameter estimates. Because our model exhibits good recovery of parameters, we can use the parameters to draw inferences about the underlying cognitive processes mediating choice behavior.

div.head: Future Directions
div.p: Future studies should further investigate the factors that influence context effects. We show that spatial order has a large influence on the three effects. In addition to spatial order, Spektor et al. (2021) identified presentation layout, attribute concreteness, and deliberation time as possible factors that impact context effects. Presentation layout refers to tabular presentations of options where attributes are either presented in columns (a by-attribute format) or rows (a by-alternative format). Attribute concreteness refers to the mode of presentation where options can be presented numerically (high concreteness) or visually / graphically (low concreteness). In a recent registered report, Hasan et al. (2023) tested the influence of spatial order, presentation layout, and attribute concreteness on the attraction effect. They found that spatial order and attribute concreteness influenced the attraction effect, but presentation layout did not. Other research has identified attribute commensurability as an important factor that can influence the attraction and compromise effects (Hayes et al., 2024). When attributes are difficult to compare within an option (e.g., price and quality), the effects are stronger than when attributes are easy to compare within an option (e.g., ratings from two reviewers). Hayes et al. (2024) showed that an extension of the modeling framework introduced in this paper can account for this phenomenon.
Future studies should also collect process data to examine the assumptions of the proposed framework. Eye tracking methods have proven to be particularly useful for this purpose.

For example, eye tracking studies have shown that in multi-alternative, multi-attribute choice tasks, pairs of options are compared on single attributes at a time (Noguchi & Stewart, 2014), pairs of similar options are attended to more frequently than pairs of dissimilar options (Noguchi & Stewart, 2014, and the inclusion of asymmetrically dominated decoys focuses attention on the target option and the dominance attribute (Marini et al., 2020). Alternative methods, such as the hidden-attribute protocol, can also be used to shed light on process mechanisms (Marini et al., 2022). An obvious application of these methods to the current framework would be to test whether people do indeed transition more frequently between adjacent options than nonadjacent options, and whether the ratio of the transition frequencies between adjacent and nonadjacent options is associated with spatial order effects in choice, as predicted by the model variants incorporating spatial attention processes.

More generally, this framework can serve as a platform to understand the consequences of different attention-related factors on decision making and under what circumstances those factors may be important. A significant strength of our approach is that it allows the researcher to explicitly model attention as part of the decision process. For example, this model could be extended to account for potential sequential dependencies in attention. For mathematical tractability, we have assumed that the conditional probabilities of transitioning to different comparisons do not depend on the past sequence of comparisons. This is likely overly restrictive and can be expanded upon in future work. Alternative forms of comparison can also be investigated. We have for simplicity assumed comparisons are within-attribute and between two items in the choice set, but comparison against other exemplars may be possible. This is just a sampling of possible extensions.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Context effects in multi-alternative, multi-attribute choice are widely documented and yet, paradoxically, quite fragile. Their elusiveness challenges previous theories of context effects, which have largely focused on explaining the existence of the effects. In this paper, we introduced a novel computational modeling framework that relies on attention modulated comparisons to explain the fragile nature of context effects. The flexibility of our framework makes it possible to test a number of different theories about the role of attention in the deliberation process. Further, we developed and validated a tractable approximation of the full model that can be used to fit choices and response time data. Using this framework, we demonstrate how attention may be critical in understanding the simultaneous generality and fragility of these effects. Generality arises from the properties of attention allocation, while fragility is a result of the ease with which that attention can be altered either intentionally or unintentionally. In summary, the proposed framework is a powerful tool for understanding the elusive nature of context effects through the lens of attentional dynamics during deliberation.

figure.figDesc: Figure 3 Attribute dependent comparison time for attention variants: Sample functions illustrating the dependence of comparison times on attribute differences. In the independent attention variant (blue), attention time does not depend on attributes. In the similarity attention variant (black), more similar alternatives are compared for longer times. In the dissimilarity variant, more distinct alternatives are compared for longer times. The dashed gray line at the bottom reflects that most cases will include a minimum comparison time. For the similarity models we use a function of the shape exp(−λ|x a i − x a j |) where x a i is the value of alternative i on attribute a. For the dissimilarity model, we use a function of the form log(1 + λ|x a i − x a j |). These are convenient functions with the appropriate shape (i.e., they are both monotonic and saturate).

Figure 4 Context effects simulation study: To study the effect of adding a decoy alternative to a binary choice, we fix the attribute values of two alternatives (x and y shown on the plot) and vary the location of a third "decoy" alternative. For each decoy value, N = 1000 simulations are run and the number of times each alternative (n(x), n(y), n(d)) is chosen (as determined by the preference accumulation process defined in equation 2) is recorded. Each plot shows the relative share of alternative x as a function of decoy location (n(x)/n(x) + n(y)). The indicated regions on the similarity variant demonstrate it simultaneously accounts for the three classic context effects. For these simulations, we use an attention parameter λ = 5 and threshold b = 0.2.

figure.figDesc: Figure 6 Accumulator mean and variance slopes as a function of λ: Here we quantify the accumulator mean and variance effect seen in Figure 5 as a function of λ. All parameters and values of the target, competitor, and decoy are the same as in Figure 5. The value of the similarity strength parameter λ is varied. For each value, we simulate 1000 independent trials and quantify the mean and variance of the traces as a function of time (see Figure 5). Since these traces are linear, we quantify the slope of mean and variance traces for the target and competitor. Those slopes are then subtracted (target -competitor) to quantify the difference in mean slopes and separately the difference in variance slopes as a function of λ. Red vertical lines indicate the value of λ used for simulations in Figure 5.

Thus, participants saw a total of six distinct orders in the experiment: TCD, TDC, CTD, DTC, CDT, and DCT. The main objective of the present analysis is to examine the three effects across the six orders. The original analysis in Trueblood et al. (2015) did not take these different orders into consideration. However, Evans et al. (2021) did use this data to examine the attraction effect for the various orders. Here we also examine the compromise and similarity effects and include the attraction effect for completeness. Below we provide an overview of the methods and refer the reader to Trueblood et al. figure.figDesc: Participant parameters for similarity plus spatial attention model: For each of the experimental participants, posterior mean parameter values were calculated. Histograms for λ and w are shown and the joint values of spatial attention parameters are shown.

for a more in depth review of the role of attention in dynamic context effects models. In MDFT, the window of attention includes all options along a single attribute. In MLBA and MDbS, attention is allocated to a pair of options along a single attribute. In MDFT and MDbS, the window of attention fluctuates stochastically over time, whereas MLBA assigns deterministic attention weights to the set of pairwise comparisons. The present framework assumes an explicit sequence of comparisons over time (specifically pairwise comparisons in the model variants studied here), with a Markov process to describe the probabilities of switching to different comparisons.

MLBA. MDbS utilizes ordinal comparisons between options instead of allowing the size of the difference between options to influence the rate of evidence accumulation as in our framework. MDFT incorporates several additional mechanisms not currently included in our framework such as distant-dependent lateral inhibition and leakage. Finally, while both MLBA and MDFT have been quantitatively tested using choice-response time data, we are unaware of such testing of MDbS. Doing so would likely require the development of a continuous approximation of the model similar to what was done here and in Evans et al. (2019).

For example,Shenoy and Yu (2013) introduced a Bayesian model in which individuals evaluate options relative to an inferred "fair market value" based on prior experience and the current choice set. Their model accounts for all three classic context effects, suggesting that such effects may emerge as rational outcomes of a decision-maker seeking to optimize choice within a relativistic framework shaped by perceived fairness. Similarly,Rigoli et al. (2017) present a

same effects. While cognitive models are essential for capturing the mechanisms of decision-making, rational approaches complement them by revealing the potential function or purpose of observed behaviors.
